title: The Complement Rule
text: The complement rule essentially explains that the proportion of the survey that answered "not sure" is equivalent to $$1$$ (or 100%) minus the sum of all the relative frequencies of those who answered in the table. Essentially, the proportion that answered "not sure" should be $$1$$ minus the sum of all the relative frequencies of those who answered <20,000; $$20, 000-25, 000;$$ $$25, 000-30, 000;$$ $$30, 000-40, 000;$$ $$40, 000-50, 000;$$ $$50, 000-75, 000;$$ $$75, 000-99, 999;$$ and 100,000+.
speech: The complement rule essentially explains that the proportion of the survey that answered "not sure" is equivalent to  1  (or 100%) minus the sum of all the relative frequencies of those who answered in the table. Essentially, the proportion that answered "not sure" should be  1  minus the sum of all the relative frequencies of those who answered <20,000:  20, comma 000 minus 25, comma, 000 colon   25, comma 000 minus 30, comma, 000 colon   30, comma 000 minus 40, comma, 000 colon   40, comma 000 minus 50, comma, 000 colon   50, comma 000 minus 75, comma, 000 colon   75, comma 000 minus 99, comma 999 colon  and 100,000+.

title: Sum of the Relative Frequencies
speech: What is the sum of the relative frequencies for those who responded <20,000:  20 comma 000 minus 25, comma, 000 colon   25, comma 000 minus 30, comma, 000 colon   30, comma 000 minus 40, comma, 000 colon   40, comma 000 minus 50, comma, 000 colon   50, comma 000 minus 75, comma, 000 colon   75, comma 000 minus 99, comma 999 colon  or 100,000+?

title: Use the Complement Rule
text: What is $$1$$ minus the sum of the relative frequencies?
speech: What is  1  minus the sum of the relative frequencies?
